Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Add restricted API for soft deleting packages " (#8290) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This PR extends the existing `DELETE /api/v2/package/{ID}/{version}` API to allow the soft deletion of packages. Currently, this endpoint can be used by any unlist scoped API key to unlist a package. This endpoint is mainly used by the `nuget.exe delete` and `dotnet nuget delete` commands to unlist packages from the command line.

The soft delete behavior is triggered by including a request body in the `DELETE` that has the following shape:
```json
{
  "Type": "SoftDelete"
}
```

If no request body is included, the `"Type"` property defaults to `"Unlist"`. This maintains backwards compatibility. In other words, the default `DELETE` behavior for nuget.org remains to unlist but a client can opt-in to the soft delete behavior with a request body parameter.

The intent of this API is to enable automation for test data clean up, i.e. the packages published by NugetTestAccount during gallery functional tests and E2E tests. 

The soft delete gesture is gated on the following conditions:
1. *(existing, same as unlist)* The target package must exist. You can still operate on a soft deleted package.
1. *(existing, same as unlist)* The API key must have the "unlist" scope.
1. *(existing, same as unlist)* The API key must have a package ID scope matching the target package.
1. *(existing, same as unlist)* The package ID must not be locked.
1. **(new, only for soft delete)** The user must be in the `NuGetGallery.DeletePackageApi` flight.
1. **(new, only for soft delete)** The user must _not_ be an admin. I don't want the risk of deleting stuff unintentionally.
1. **(new, only for soft delete)** The package download count must not be greater than or equal to 1000.

I will present a full design before moving forward, but generally my plan is to roll this out and write a simple task in the `Gallery.Maintenance` job to call this delete API on packages owned by `NugetTestAccount`.

I chose to make this a REST API so that the complex, multistep delete logic is deployed only to a single location (gallery front-end) instead of multiple places (gallery front-end and some delete job). I have no intent of opening this API up to anyone but `NugetTestAccount`, but the code is written in such a way that it could be extended to future scenarios.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Prototype UI Enhancements & prepare for User Study" (#10274) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Time-boxed effort to create prototype(s) for enhancements to various PM UI functions. The Epic serves as a guide for customer input.
Prepare these prototype(s) for the next User Study to solicit feedback.

Some ideas:
- Scope any remaining work for Version Range support https://github.com/nuget/home/issues/6566

- Bonus would be to investigate GitHub commit integration: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/8585

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Prototype a Package Source Error Handler & prepare for User Study" (#10273) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Time-boxed effort to create prototype(s) for how the PM UI handles errors with Package Sources. The Epic serves as a guide for customer input.
Prepare these prototype(s) for the next User Study to solicit feedback.

Consider:

- How to show a failing feed but keep the UI functional: https://github.com/nuget/home/issues/9218

- How to avoid infinite Authentication popups: https://github.com/nuget/home/issues/5028

- How can we show validation issues: Warn or error when no package sources exist #2472

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Test:  package signing tests sometimes fail with 0xC0000001 (STATUS_UNSUCCESSFUL)" (#8418) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
According to @bartonjs, this is tracked by https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/issues/37994.

Example from one CI test run:
```

---- System.Security.Cryptography.CryptographicException : Unknown error "-1073741823".
---- The following constructor parameters did not have matching fixture data: CertificatesFixture fixture
Stack Trace:

        at System.Security.Cryptography.NCryptNative.SignHash[T](SafeNCryptKeyHandle key, Byte[] hash, T& paddingInfo, AsymmetricPaddingMode paddingMode, NCryptHashSigner`1 signer)
        at System.Security.Cryptography.NCryptNative.SignHashPkcs1(SafeNCryptKeyHandle key, Byte[] hash, String hashAlgorithm)
        at System.Security.Cryptography.RSACng.SignHash(Byte[] hash, HashAlgorithmName hashAlgorithm, RSASignaturePadding padding)
        at System.Security.Cryptography.RSA.SignData(Byte[] data, Int32 offset, Int32 count, HashAlgorithmName hashAlgorithm, RSASignaturePadding padding)
        at System.Security.Cryptography.RSA.SignData(Byte[] data, HashAlgorithmName hashAlgorithm, RSASignaturePadding padding)

        at System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.CertificateRequest.Create(X500DistinguishedName issuerName, X509SignatureGenerator generator, DateTimeOffset notBefore, DateTimeOffset notAfter, Byte[] serialNumber)
        at System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.CertificateRequest.CreateSelfSigned(DateTimeOffset notBefore, DateTimeOffset notAfter)
    E:\A\_work\118\s\test\TestUtilities\Test.Utility\Signing\SigningTestUtility.cs(309,0): at Test.Utility.Signing.SigningTestUtility.GenerateCertificate(String subjectName, Action`1 modifyGenerator, RSA rsa, HashAlgorithmName hashAlgorithm, RSASignaturePaddingMode paddingMode, ChainCertificateRequest chainCertificateRequest)
    E:\A\_work\118\s\test\TestUtilities\Test.Utility\Signing\SigningTestUtility.cs(212,0): at Test.Utility.Signing.SigningTestUtility.GenerateCertificate(String subjectName, Action`1 modifyGenerator, HashAlgorithmName hashAlgorithm, RSASignaturePaddingMode paddingMode, Int32 publicKeyLength, ChainCertificateRequest chainCertificateRequest)
    E:\A\_work\118\s\test\NuGet.Core.Tests\NuGet.Packaging.Test\SigningTests\CertificatesFixture.cs(36,0): at NuGet.Packaging.Test.CertificatesFixture..ctor()
    ----- Inner Stack Trace #2 (Xunit.Sdk.TestClassException) -----
          
System.AggregateException : One or more errors occurred.
---- System.Security.Cryptography.CryptographicException : Unknown error "-1073741823".
---- The following constructor parameters did not have matching fixture data: CertificatesFixture fixture
Stack Trace:
          
    ----- Inner Stack Trace #1 (System.Security.Cryptography.CryptographicException) -----
        at System.Security.Cryptography.NCryptNative.SignHash[T](SafeNCryptKeyHandle key, Byte[] hash, T& paddingInfo, AsymmetricPaddingMode paddingMode, NCryptHashSigner`1 signer)
        at System.Security.Cryptography.NCryptNative.SignHashPkcs1(SafeNCryptKeyHandle key, Byte[] hash, String hashAlgorithm)
        at System.Security.Cryptography.RSACng.SignHash(Byte[] hash, HashAlgorithmName hashAlgorithm, RSASignaturePadding padding)
        at System.Security.Cryptography.RSA.SignData(Byte[] data, Int32 offset, Int32 count, HashAlgorithmName hashAlgorithm, RSASignaturePadding padding)
        at System.Security.Cryptography.RSA.SignData(Byte[] data, HashAlgorithmName hashAlgorithm, RSASignaturePadding padding)
        at System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.RSAPkcs1X509SignatureGenerator.SignData(Byte[] data, HashAlgorithmName hashAlgorithm)
        at System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.TbsCertificate.Sign(X509SignatureGenerator signatureGenerator, HashAlgorithmName hashAlgorithm)
        at System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.CertificateRequest.Create(X500DistinguishedName issuerName, X509SignatureGenerator generator, DateTimeOffset notBefore, DateTimeOffset notAfter, Byte[] serialNumber)
        at System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.CertificateRequest.CreateSelfSigned(DateTimeOffset notBefore, DateTimeOffset notAfter)
    E:\A\_work\118\s\test\TestUtilities\Test.Utility\Signing\SigningTestUtility.cs(309,0): at Test.Utility.Signing.SigningTestUtility.GenerateCertificate(String subjectName, Action`1 modifyGenerator, RSA rsa, HashAlgorithmName hashAlgorithm, RSASignaturePaddingMode paddingMode, ChainCertificateRequest chainCertificateRequest)
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Missing Nuget.Commandline 5.8.0 package" (#10267) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

It looks like all NuGet related packages have had a 5.8.0 release on nuget.org except NuGet.CommandLine which is still on 5.7.0.
This makes our CI builds fail when using .Net SDK 5.0.100 and the Cake build system. Cake references the NuGet.CommandLine package to ensure a nuget.exe file is available. NuGet versions < 5.8 seem to generate assets files without the TargetFrameworkAlias property, which ultimately fails our build with a bunch of NETSDK1005 errors.

Is the NuGet.CommandLine package on a different release schedule?

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Navigate to https://www.nuget.org/downloads where the latest version is 5.8.0 indicating this is the latest available release

2. Navigate to https://www.nuget.org/packages/NuGet.CommandLine/ where the latest version is still 5.7.0

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug Bash] Duplicate lines show in Output->Package Manager window after installing a package" (#10266) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev\5.9.0.6966
VS Version: Master\30712.41
OS: Windows-10-Enterprise-19H2
## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem
1. Open VS and click File->New->Project and search the template ‚ÄúASP.NET Empty Web Site‚Äù.
2. Type the project name and click the ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù button.
3. Open project PM UI, go to ‚ÄúBrowse‚Äù tab and install a package (e.g. Newtonsoft.Json).
4. Select ‚ÄúPackage Manager‚Äù in the top of Output window.
## Expected
No duplicate lines show.
## Actual
Duplicate lines show in Output->Package Manager window as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/99084975-9534fd00-2602-11eb-84d5-e56296ba69e0.png)
## Notes
We will verify the regression info later.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug Bash][Unstable] Error ‚Äúcould not load file or assembly 'Microsoft.CodeDom.Providers.DotNetCompilerPlatform‚Äù occurred after updating all the packages in ASP.NET Web Forms Site" (#10265) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev\5.9.0.6966
VS Version: Master\30712.41
OS: Windows-10-Enterprise-19H2
## Detailed repro steps
1. Open any solution via VS, (**don‚Äôt close the solution/VS-it is easy to repro the bug**) click File->New->Project and click the template ‚ÄúASP.NET Web Forms Site‚Äù.
2. Type the project name and click the ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù button.
3. Open project PM UI, go to ‚ÄúUpdates‚Äù tab, check ‚ÄúSelect all packages‚Äù check-box and click ‚ÄúUpdate‚Äù button.
4. Click ‚ÄúOK‚Äù button in the prompt ‚ÄúPreview Changes‚Äù window.
5. Click ‚ÄúYes to All‚Äù button in the prompt File Conflict dialog as below.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/99084342-c6f99400-2601-11eb-819a-bf74dabe1471.png)
## Expected
Updating is successful without any error.
## Actual
Error ‚Äúcould not load file or assembly 'Microsoft.CodeDom.Providers.DotNetCompilerPlatform‚Äù occurred in Error List window as below. Repro rate: 10%
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/99084473-f3151500-2601-11eb-8245-be6a6d156813.png)
## Notes
1.Error Message: Could not load file or assembly 'Microsoft.CodeDom.Providers.DotNetCompilerPlatform, Version=3.6.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=31bf3856ad364e35' or one of its dependencies. The located assembly's manifest definition does not match the assembly reference. (Exception from HRESULT: 0x80131040).
2.We will verify the regression info later.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Feature request: persistently specify allowed version ranges for package references" (#10264) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): VS UI

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 5.8.0

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): N/A

VS version (if appropriate): VS 2019 Enterprise 16.8.1

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): Windows 10 Pro version 2004 (OS build 19041.630)

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: N/A

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. I have a **.NET Core 3.1** csproj with a package reference defined as the following:

```xml
<PackageReference Include="Microsoft.Extensions.Options.ConfigurationExtensions" Version="3.1.9" />
```

Since .NET 5.0 was recently released, but is not LTS, my organisation does not allow us to update to version 5.0.0 of the various packages. However, we should keep up-to-date with whatever versions of the 3.1 branch, and they just released version 3.1.10, so I want to update to that version of this package.

2. Going into the NuGet UI for the project in question, it suggests the version 5.0.0 package as the update, which I **do not want**. I also do not want that anyone else (e.g. juniors) can see this, as they might try updating to this version.

3. Therefore, I edit the csproj to use a [version range](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/concepts/package-versioning#version-ranges) to constrain the allowable versions:

```xml
<PackageReference Include="Microsoft.Extensions.Options.ConfigurationExtensions" Version="[3.1.9,5.0.0)" />
```

4. Reloading the project and going into the NuGet UI again, things are now correct: the UI prompts me to update to version 3.1.10. I click to update to that version.

5. The package updates, the NuGet UI refreshes, and... **now it  prompts me to upgrade to version 5.0.0 again**. Looking at the csproj file, the reason becomes obvious - my range expression has been nuked by the update:

```xml
<PackageReference Include="Microsoft.Extensions.Options.ConfigurationExtensions" Version="3.1.10" />
```

However, I would argue that it's **incorrect** to allow a range expression in the `Version` attribute anyway. To my mind, the `Version` attribute should specify the **explicit version** of this dependency that is **currently referenced**.

What is needed, in my opinion, is a new attribute on the `PackageReference` node to encapsulate the concept of "allowed version range", that won't be mutated when a package is updated. Something like `AllowedVersions`:

```xml
<PackageReference Include="Microsoft.Extensions.Options.ConfigurationExtensions" Version="3.1.9" AllowedVersions="(,5.0.0)" />
```

With that implemented, I would expect to open the NuGet UI in VS and only be presented with an option to upgrade to version 3.1.10. The upgrade would then rewrite the csproj to contain the following:

```xml
<PackageReference Include="Microsoft.Extensions.Options.ConfigurationExtensions" Version="3.1.10" AllowedVersions="(,5.0.0)" />
```

and consequently, the NuGet VS UI would **not** offer me the option to upgrade to version 5.0.0 of the package.

By default, `AllowedVersions` would be absent, which would mean the behaviour would be equivalent to NuGet's current "offer the highest version available".

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug Bash][Unstable] Error ‚Äúfailed to add reference to 'Microsoft.Owin.Security.Cookies'‚Äù occurred after updating all the packages in ASP.NET Web Application (.NET Framework)-Single Page Application" (#10263) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev\5.9.0.6966
VS Version: Master\30712.41
OS: Windows-10-Enterprise-19H2
## Detailed repro steps
1. Open any solution via VS, **(don‚Äôt close the solution/VS-it is easy to repro the bug)** click File->New->Project and click the template ‚ÄúASP.NET Web Application (.NET Framework)‚Äù.
2. Type the project name, click the ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù button and select ‚ÄúSingle Page Application‚Äù.
3. Open project PM UI, go to ‚ÄúUpdates‚Äù tab, check ‚ÄúSelect all packages‚Äù check-box and click ‚ÄúUpdate‚Äù button.
4. Click ‚ÄúOK‚Äù button in the prompt ‚ÄúPreview Changes‚Äù window.
## Expected
Updating is successful without any error.
## Actual
Error ‚Äúfailed to add reference to 'Microsoft.Owin.Security.Cookies'‚Äù occurred in Error List window as below. Repro rate: 20%
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/99083973-43d83e00-2601-11eb-9270-cf22bb3bb9f2.png)
## Note
1.Error Message: Failed to add reference to 'Microsoft.Owin.Security.Cookies'.A reference to the component 'Microsoft.Owin.Security.Cookies' already exists in the project.
2.We will verify the regression info later.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Security: Should random code execution in target files be at least something you warn about?" (#10262) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Remove the content above here and fill out details below.

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): VS UI

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): current

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): doesn't matter

VS version (if appropriate): doesn't matter

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): doesn't matter

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: has probably always been a problem

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Install https://www.nuget.org/packages/IAmRoot/ NuGet package

2. Build your solution

3. Some C# code hidden away in a targets file in the NuGet package is executed on my machine without me noticing

...

### Sample Project

See https://github.com/augustoproiete/i-am-root-nuget-package

To me this sounds like a security flaw in the NuGet design. My understanding was that this is not possible anymore after you removed support for Install/Uninstall.ps1 in NuGet packages. Is there some documentation about the consequences? Is it possible to add warnings if there are target files in the package maybe even only if target files contain arbitrary C# code and/or use tasks which try to go outside the solution directory?

I haven't thought about all the consequences yet, but this sounds like a problem to me.

Best regards,
D. R.

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "November dry run for custom V2 OData query deprecation" (#48) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/37) last year and we will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in **February 2021**. 

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
¬†
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	¬∑ **Nov. 11, 2020** ‚Äì 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	¬∑ **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**¬† ‚Äì¬†48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).
¬†
Refer to the table below to identify the test slot time in your time zone.
	¬∑ UTC-9 to UTC-2 ‚Äì¬†[Green test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Green+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3923&ah=4)
	¬∑ UTC-1 to UTC+6 ‚Äì¬†[Yellow test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Yellow+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3915&ah=4)
	¬∑ UTC+7 to UTC-10 ‚Äì¬†[Blue test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Blue+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3909&ah=4)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "November dry run for custom V2 OData query deprecation" (#48) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/37) last year and we will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in **February 2021**. 

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
¬†
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	¬∑ **Nov. 11, 2020** ‚Äì 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	¬∑ **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**¬† ‚Äì¬†48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).
¬†
Refer to the table below to identify the test slot time in your time zone.
	¬∑ UTC-9 to UTC-2 ‚Äì¬†[Green test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Green+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3923&ah=4)
	¬∑ UTC-1 to UTC+6 ‚Äì¬†[Yellow test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Yellow+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3915&ah=4)
	¬∑ UTC+7 to UTC-10 ‚Äì¬†[Blue test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Blue+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3909&ah=4)
